title: Minimizing Weighted Sum Download Time for One-to-Many File Transfer in Peer-to-Peer Networks
summary: This paper focuses on minimizing the weighted sum download time (WSDT) for one-to-many file transfer in peer-to-peer networks. It considers heterogeneous peers with both uplink and downlink bandwidth constraints, and proposes several schemes to optimize WSDT, including a static routing-based scheme and a dynamic rateless-coding-based scheme.
methodology: The paper uses linear network coding and convex optimization to solve the problem of minimizing WSDT. It also proposes a water-filling approach using depth-1 and depth-2 trees.
research_outcomes: The paper presents several schemes to optimize WSDT, including a static routing-based scheme and a dynamic rateless-coding-based scheme. It also shows that the water-filling approach provides a simple algorithm that empirically achieves the lower bound on WSDT for all cases of the static scenario.

title: Implementation of use case point as software effort estimation in Scrum Framework
summary: This paper explores the implementation of Use Case Point (UCP) as a method for software effort estimation within the Scrum framework. The authors investigate how UCP can be integrated with Scrum to improve estimation accuracy and efficiency.
methodology: The research follows a three-stage approach: identifying the estimation process with UCP, examining the mechanism of implementation of Scrum framework to find UCP and Scrum integration, and developing a simulation application.
research_outcomes: The study finds that UCP can be integrated with Scrum by associating User Stories on the Product Backlog with Use Cases on UCP and modifying User Story attributes. The results show improved estimation accuracy and efficiency compared to traditional methods.

title: Online monitoring of water pollution level based on dissolved oxygen (DO) and biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) using wireless sensor system
summary: This paper proposes an online monitoring system for water pollution levels based on dissolved oxygen (DO) and biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) using a wireless sensor system. The system uses database replication to ensure consistency and prevent redundant data, providing reliable information on the web.
methodology: The paper proposes an online monitoring system that combines a wireless sensor system with database replication to monitor water pollution levels based on DO and BOD.
research_outcomes: The proposed system ensures consistency, prevents redundant data, and provides reliable information on the web.

title: Analysis of Drivers’ Eye Movements on Roundabouts:A Driving Simulator Study
summary: This study investigates drivers' eye movements under distracted and non-distracted conditions on roundabouts using a driving simulator. The research focuses on the visual characteristics relevant to distracted driving, but does not involve any machine learning or AI methods.
methodology: The study used a driving simulator with an eye tracker to assess drivers' behaviors on roundabouts under different conditions.
research_outcomes: The results indicated that, under distracting conditions, the drivers' fixation duration decreased significantly on roundabouts, and pupil size increased significantly.

title: A Whole-Body Software Abstraction layer for Control Design of free-floating Mechanical Systems
summary: This paper proposes a software abstraction layer to simplify the design and synthesis of whole-body controllers without making any preliminary assumptions on the control law. The library decouples the control software from implementation details, providing a clean and concise code that focuses only on the implementation of the control law.
methodology: The proposed library uses a model-based driven approach to provide a scalable and easily portable solution for whole-body control.
research_outcomes: The paper presents a reference implementation of the abstraction layer together with a Simulink interface, and shows the implementation of two controllers: a simple proportional-derivative plus gravity compensation controller and a more complex momentum-based bipedal balance controller.

title: qprof: a gprof-inspired quantum profiler
summary: This paper introduces qprof, a new and extensible quantum program profiler that generates profiling reports of various quantum circuits. The tool is designed to be modular and extensible, allowing it to support multiple quantum computing frameworks. qprof aims to replace the manual process of finding hotspots in quantum implementations by automatically generating a report with useful information.
methodology: The qprof tool uses a plugin architecture to be extensible and framework-agnostic, allowing it to support multiple quantum computing frameworks. It uses an abstract common interface to represent the concept of 'quantum (sub)routine'.
research_outcomes: qprof is able to generate profiling reports of various quantum circuits, making it easier for researchers to visualize their quantum implementation and locate bottlenecks.

title: BitSurfing: Wireless Communications with Outsourced Symbol Generation
summary: This paper proposes a new network adapter architecture, BitSurfing, which overcomes implementation challenges in nano-IoT by outsourcing symbol generation to an external source. The BitSurfing adapter reads incoming symbols and waits for intended messages to appear in the stream, emitting short pulses to notify neighboring nodes.
methodology: The methodology involves a novel network adapter architecture that relies on an external symbol generator, allowing for perpetual operation and payload maximization.
research_outcomes: The BitSurfing adapters exhibit perpetual operation, ability to operate without medium access control, and are completely transparent to applications. They offer nearly-perfect packet delivery rates and practically no collisions under any congestion level.

title: Beyond connectedness: why pairwise metrics cannot capture community stability
summary: This paper examines the limitations of pairwise metrics in capturing community stability, proposing an alternative metric based on feedback loops. The authors argue that pairwise interactions are insufficient to understand system stability and introduce a new approach using three-link feedback loops.
methodology: The authors use Jacobian community matrix models to analyze the local stability of observed food-web structures. They compare the performance of two recently proposed metrics: one based on feedback loops and another on pairwise interactions.
research_outcomes: The study shows that pairwise metrics are unable to capture the complex organization of strong and weak links in a community, which is essential for system stability. The authors propose an alternative metric based on three-link feedback loops, which better estimates stability.

title: Estimation of Exciton Diffusion Lengths of Organic Semiconductors in Random Domains
summary: This paper focuses on estimating exciton diffusion lengths in organic semiconductors with random domains. The authors employ a diffusion-type equation as the forward model and propose an asymptotic-based method to solve it, demonstrating its efficiency compared to stochastic collocation methods.
methodology: The authors use a diffusion-type equation with appropriate boundary conditions as the forward model and extract the exciton diffusion length in an inverse manner. Surface roughness is treated as a random function.
research_outcomes: The proposed asymptotic-based method shows improved efficiency compared to stochastic collocation methods, and its accuracy is justified both analytically and numerically.

title: Construction of 5G all-wireless network and information system for cabin hospitals
summary: This paper presents a 5G all-wireless solution to divide the overall network system of cabin hospitals into multiple network units by function. The solution uses virtual private networks (VPNs) built on the 5G wireless network to connect each network unit to the host hospital's data center, ensuring secure and encrypted data transmission.
methodology: The authors used a divide-and-conquer approach to design the 5G all-wireless solution, dividing the overall network system into multiple network units by function. They also developed a cloud-based network management platform for remote monitoring and control.
research_outcomes: The proposed solution was successfully implemented in over 20 cabin hospitals, providing reliable and efficient communication services to medical staff and patients.

title: Universal consistency and rates of convergence of multiclass prototype algorithms in metric spaces
summary: This paper studies the universal consistency and convergence rates of simple nearest-neighbor prototype rules for multiclass classification in metric spaces. The authors introduce a novel data-dependent partitioning rule, Proto-NN, which is universally consistent in any metric space that admits a universally consistent rule. They also derive rates for the k-NN rule under a generalized Lipschitz condition and margin condition.
methodology: The paper uses a combination of theoretical analysis and empirical evaluation to study the performance of prototype algorithms in metric spaces.
research_outcomes: The authors show that Proto-NN is universally consistent and derive rates for the k-NN rule under certain conditions. They also introduce a hybridization between Proto-NN and k-NN, which achieves similar rates as k-NN while enjoying reduced computational complexity.

title: WiNV: A Framework for Web-based Interactive Scalable Network Visualization
summary: This paper presents a new state-of-the-art network visualization framework, WiNV, which enables interactive and scalable visualization of large-scale networks in a web browser without the need for plugins or special-purpose runtime systems. The framework uses AJAX-based DWR technology to generate network elements on-the-fly, allowing for smooth interaction and editing capabilities.
methodology: The WiNV framework is designed as a thin-client native application with a modular architecture, consisting of four tiers: presentation, server, network, and persistent. The framework uses AJAX-based DWR technology to generate network elements on-the-fly, allowing for smooth interaction and editing capabilities.
research_outcomes: The WiNV framework enables interactive and scalable visualization of large-scale networks in a web browser without the need for plugins or special-purpose runtime systems. The framework provides two modes: Standalone mode and Google Earth mode, with configurable options for network visualization.

title: Achieving Fair Random Access Performance in Massive MIMO Crowded Machine-Type Networks
summary: This paper proposes a novel random access protocol, ACBPC, that improves fairness and performance in crowded machine-type networks. Unlike previous protocols like SUCRe, which favors UEs closer to the base station, ACBPC enables UEs to estimate the number of contenders for a pilot without additional overhead, leading to improved spectral efficiency and energy efficiency.
methodology: The proposed protocol uses a decentralized power control policy to adjust pilot transmit power inversely proportional to long-term fading coefficients. This allows UEs to have similar success connection probabilities regardless of their distances to the base station.
research_outcomes: Numerical results demonstrate that ACBPC outperforms SUCRe in terms of fairness and performance, achieving a uniform probability of collision resolution as a function of distance to the base station. The proposed protocol also achieves energy savings up to 88% compared to SUCRe.

title: Network De-materialization in Open Flow Network
summary: This review paper presents the study of DeMaterialization of Network known as Network Virtualization in SDN. It interprets different paths to network virtualization and defines contrasting mechanisms for resource allocation.
methodology: The methodology involves the abstraction layer provided by Network Hypervisor, which maps logical forwarding plane to underlying physical hardware.
research_outcomes: Key findings include the importance of network virtualization and the need for fair resource allocation. The paper also discusses the use of Open Flow and Flowvisor techniques for control side virtualization.

title: Numerical integration in arbitrary-precision ball arithmetic
summary: This paper presents an implementation of rigorous numerical integration with error bounds in the Arb library, using a combination of adaptive bisection and Gaussian quadrature. The code is general, easy to use, and efficient, often outperforming existing non-rigorous software.
methodology: The paper uses a combination of adaptive bisection and Gaussian quadrature for numerical integration with error bounds.
research_outcomes: The implementation achieves high precision and accuracy, often outperforming existing non-rigorous software.

title: Assessment of transferable forcefields for protein simulations
summary: This paper assesses the performance of four mainstream, transferable, nonpolarizable forcefields in simulating protein solutions and disordered states. The authors tested these forcefields for their ability to accurately describe disorder with secondary structure propensity and keep proteins soluble or insoluble as required. The study focuses on improving the simulation of disordered peptides and proteins, a problem that has been understudied despite its importance.
methodology: Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations using atomistic transferable forcefields
research_outcomes: The study found that the modern forcefields tested are able to accurately describe disorder with secondary structure propensity and keep proteins soluble or insoluble as required. The results suggest that the development of better water models is key for simulations to produce less compact ensembles of disordered proteins.

title: Patch Quality and Diversity of Invariant-Guided Search-Based Program Repair
summary: This paper evaluates the correctness and diversity of patches generated by GenProg and an invariant-based diversity-enhancing extension. The authors find no evidence that promoting diversity changes the correctness of patches, but do observe semantic differences between patches for most bugs.
methodology: The authors use held-out tests to evaluate patch correctness and semantic diversity metrics based on inferred invariants and automatic test case generation tools to measure patch diversity.
research_outcomes: The study finds that promoting diversity does not improve patch correctness, but does observe semantic differences between patches for most bugs.

title: Challenges in migrating legacy software systems to the cloud: An empirical study
summary: This paper investigates the challenges of migrating legacy software systems to the cloud, highlighting the need for a holistic understanding of the migration process and addressing key internal operational difficulties. The study emphasizes the importance of considering socio-technical aspects and reengineering processes to enable interaction with and utilization of cloud services.
methodology: The paper uses a combination of bottom-up and top-down analysis, deriving common activities from extant cloud computing literature and validating them using a population of domain experts. A Web-based survey questionnaire was used to collect data, which were analyzed using SPSS Sample T-Test.
research_outcomes: The study identifies key challenges in migrating legacy systems to the cloud, including inadequate understanding of cloud computing requirements, early engagement with technical implementation phase, lack of planning, and facing unexpected issues. It provides a practical guide for conducting this transition.

title: Hybrid PSOGSA Technique for Solving Dynamic Economic Emission Dispatch Problem
summary: This paper proposes a hybrid population-based algorithm combining particle swarm optimization (PSO) and gravitational search algorithm (GSA) techniques to solve the dynamic economic emission dispatch problem. The proposed method integrates exploration abilities of PSO with GSA's strength, demonstrating efficiency and superiority over other optimization algorithms.
methodology: The hybrid PSOGSA technique is implemented using a 5-unit test system to minimize fuel cost and emissions under constraints.
research_outcomes: The results show the effectiveness of the proposed method in solving the dynamic economic emission dispatch problem.

title: Territories of data: ontological divergences in the growth of data infrastructure
summary: This paper explores the intersection of data infrastructure and territorial conflicts in Chile, arguing that the expansion of data infrastructure can impinge upon the cultivation of worlds based on human and other-than-human interdependence. The authors adopt a political ontology lens to examine divergent ontologies of territory emerging in relation to astronomy data infrastructure.
methodology: discursive-material analysis of interviews and documents
research_outcomes: The study identifies two ontologies of territory (assetized and relational) mobilized in relation to astronomy data in Chile, highlighting the need for a more nuanced understanding of territorial conflicts.

title: Impact of Mobile Phone Usage on Some Health Aspects of Children and Adolescents: Evidence Based Review Article
summary: This paper reviews the impact of mobile phone usage on various health aspects of children and adolescents, including eye health, ear problems, neurological effects, psychiatric effects, and brain tumors. The study finds that prolonged use of mobile phones can cause visual disturbances, auditory problems, headaches, and increased risk of depression and anxiety in young users.
methodology: Evidentiary subject review study to reveal the results of newly published research about the impact of mobile phone usage on some health aspects on children and adolescents
research_outcomes: The study finds that prolonged use of mobile phones can cause visual disturbances, auditory problems, headaches, and increased risk of depression and anxiety in young users.

title: The Software System Implementation of Speech Command Recognizer Under Intensive Background Noise
summary: This paper presents a speech command recognition system that uses adaptive filtering noise cancellation and HMM-based connected-word speech recognition algorithm to improve robustness in strong noise environments. The ML impact is substantial as the system relies heavily on machine learning techniques for speech enhancement and recognition.
methodology: The methodology involves using two microphones to sample background noise and noisy speech signals, followed by adaptive filtering noise cancellation and HMM-based connected-word speech recognition algorithm.
research_outcomes: The system shows improved robustness in strong noise environments with a signal-to-noise ratio increase of more than 20 dB. The speech recognizer is sensitive to initial position error, but the double threshold detection method based on short-term average energy improves accuracy.

title: Design and Implementation of ATM Security System using IOT
summary: This paper proposes a low-cost and efficient security system for ATMs using IoT technology. The system uses various sensors, including RFID readers, smoke sensors, metal detectors, and force sensors to detect potential threats and alert authorities.
methodology: The proposed system uses an Arduino-based microcontroller board with various sensors and actuators to implement a secure ATM system.
research_outcomes: The paper presents a functional block diagram of the proposed system, including its components and working principles. The authors also discuss the software requirements for programming the system.

title: An Optimal Mass Transport Method for Random Genetic Drift
summary: This paper proposes an optimal mass transport method for random genetic drift, focusing on the Moran process and its large population limits. The method is designed to capture Dirac-delta singularities and preserve biologically relevant properties of the random genetic drift.
methodology: The proposed numerical method uses a gradient flow structure and variational schemes to solve the Kimura equation, which describes the probability of fixation of a mutant with frequency-independent fitness. The method is designed to capture Dirac-delta singularities and preserve biologically relevant properties of the random genetic drift.
research_outcomes: The paper presents a new numerical scheme for solving the Kimura equation, which can accurately capture the concentration phenomena at the discrete level. The scheme is based on the gradient flow structure and variational schemes, and it preserves several biologically relevant properties of the random genetic drift.

title: Secure Sensor Design Against Undetected Infiltration: Minimum Impact-Minimum Damage
summary: This paper proposes a new defense mechanism against undetected infiltration into controllers in cyber-physical systems, focusing on minimizing damage before detection. The approach involves cautious design of sensor outputs to improve security further when combined with other defense mechanisms.
methodology: The authors use game-theoretic hierarchical equilibrium and semi-definite programming to compute optimal linear secure sensor outputs and analyze performance for various scenarios.
research_outcomes: The proposed approach can improve the security of cyber-physical systems by minimizing damage before detection, but its effectiveness depends on the specific system and scenario.
